questions.question: What’s one big downside of using a physical server to run an app?

options.It’s hard to plug in: That’s not the problem, setup isn’t the issue. Scaling is.
options.It only works on Wi-Fi: Nope! Physical servers can be wired or wireless. That’s not the issue.
options.It’s expensive and doesn’t adjust when t: Correct! Physical servers are powerful but rigid. They can’t flex when traffic spikes.
options.You can’t install software on it: You can definitely install software. That’s what they’re made for.

questions.correct: It’s expensive and doesn’t adjust when traffic increases

questions.question: How are virtual machines (VMs) better than physical servers?

options.They’re free to use: Not quite. Cloud VMs usually cost money too.
options.You can run more than one app on the sam: Correct! VMs let you share hardware by running multiple isolated systems.
options.They turn into containers automatically: Nope. VMs and containers are different technologies.
options.They never crash: That would be nice… but not true.

questions.correct: You can run more than one app on the same machine

questions.question: What makes containers so useful for modern apps?

options.They come with free internet: Fun idea, but nope. Network config isn’t automatic magic.
options.They fix bugs on their own: Wouldn’t that be nice? You still need developers for that.
options.They start quickly and can grow or shrin: Correct! Containers are lightweight and work great with autoscaling.
options.They use more electricity: Actually, they tend to be more efficient than traditional setups.

questions.correct: They start quickly and can grow or shrink depending on traffic

questions.question: Why have we moved from servers to VMs to containers?

options.Because newer tools look cooler: Looks don’t matter, scalability and resilience do.
options.Because apps are smaller now: Apps may be smaller, but that’s not the reason for the shift.
options.Because we need systems that can grow, r: Correct! The evolution is all about building systems that adapt and survive at scale.
options.Because VMs stopped working: VMs still work. Containers just offer more flexibility.

questions.correct: Because we need systems that can grow, recover, and keep running without manual work

questions.question: In the transportation analogy from TM-001, what are containers most like?

options.Owning a sports car: That’s more like a physical server, powerful, but limited to one use.
options.Riding a train that adds cars when more: Correct! Containers are like train cars that are modular, scalable, and efficient.
options.Driving a rental truck: Closer to a VM, flexible but heavier than a container.

questions.correct: Riding a train that adds cars when more people show up
